liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: So far the best performer on the ASX today is United Malt Group — they were up 9% at lunch time, and it's all thanks to their impending takeover by French malt company. United Malt Group told the ASX this morning they'd entered into a scheme implementation deed with Malteries Soufflet, in a deal that values United Malt at a staggering $1.5 billion. Directors of United Malt have unanimously recommended that shareholders vote in favour of the takeover at the scheme meeting. United Malt says the offer by Malteries Soufflet will see each shareholder receive $5.00 per United Malt share in cash — which is equivalent to a 45.3% premium to the company's closing share price on March 24 this year. Malteries Soufflet is a branch of the French agribusiness giant InVivo, and the deal will likely see the creation of the world's top malt producer. United Malt is the world's fourth-largest commercial maltster, and produces malt for brewers, craft brewers, distillers and food companies, and has processing plants in Australian, Canada, the US and Britain.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: United Malt is leading the charge on the ASX today — here's why

children.content: So far the best performer on the ASX today is United Malt Group — they were up 9% at lunch time, and it's all thanks to their impending takeover by French malt company.
United Malt Group told the ASX this morning they'd entered into a scheme implementation deed with Malteries Soufflet, in a deal that values United Malt at a staggering $1.5 billion.
Directors of United Malt have unanimously recommended that shareholders vote in favour of the takeover at the scheme meeting.

United Malt says the offer by Malteries Soufflet will see each shareholder receive $5.00 per United Malt share in cash — which is equivalent to a 45.3% premium to the company's closing share price on March 24 this year.
Malteries Soufflet is a branch of the French agribusiness giant InVivo, and the deal will likely see the creation of the world's top malt producer.

United Malt is the world's fourth-largest commercial maltster, and produces malt for brewers, craft brewers, distillers and food companies, and has processing plants in Australian, Canada, the US and Britain.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The latest building approvals data for May has been published by the ABS this morning, finding that the total number of dwellings approved has risen by 20.6%, after a decline of 6.8% in April. But despite the monthly rise, the yearly building approvals rate has fallen by 9.8% year-on-year. The ABS says the rise is mainly due to a large number of apartments being approved in New South Wales in May, while approvals for standalone houses was relatively flat in comparison. "Approvals for private sector houses remain more subdued, rising 0.9 per cent, following a 3.0 per cent fall in April," Daniel Rossi, ABS head of construction statistics, said. Victoria was the only state that saw an increase in approvals for private sector houses (+7.3%), with falls in all other states.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Building approvals rise after more apartment developments greenlit in NSW

children.content: The latest building approvals data for May has been published by the ABS this morning, finding that the total number of dwellings approved has risen by 20.6%, after a decline of 6.8% in April.
But despite the monthly rise, the yearly building approvals rate has fallen by 9.8% year-on-year.
The ABS says the rise is mainly due to a large number of apartments being approved in New South Wales in May, while approvals for standalone houses was relatively flat in comparison.
"Approvals for private sector houses remain more subdued, rising 0.9 per cent, following a 3.0 per cent fall in April," Daniel Rossi, ABS head of construction statistics, said.
Victoria was the only state that saw an increase in approvals for private sector houses (+7.3%), with falls in all other states.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In light of PwC Australia naming and sacking eight of its partners for their involvement in the tax scandal, the firm's acting CEO Kristin Stubbins says those involved are now being held accountable for their actions. Stubbins was appointed as PwC's acting CEO after Tom Seymour stepped down in the wake of the scandal. Seymour has since been identified as one of the partners involved in the "failure of leadership" behind the tax leak, and is among those who have been sacked from the firm in today's announcement. "Accountability is critical to improving our culture and based on our investigation to date, it is clear that the conduct of a number of partners fell short of what was expected of them," Ms Stubbins said. "They are now being held accountable for their misconduct. "While we cannot change the past, we can control our actions today and in the future. "Moving forward, the PwC Australia management team will continue to take all appropriate steps to improve the firm’s culture and standards."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Acting PwC CEO says sacked partners are 'being held accountable'

children.content: In light of PwC Australia naming and sacking eight of its partners for their involvement in the tax scandal, the firm's acting CEO Kristin Stubbins says those involved are now being held accountable for their actions.
Stubbins was appointed as PwC's acting CEO after Tom Seymour stepped down in the wake of the scandal.
Seymour has since been identified as one of the partners involved in the "failure of leadership" behind the tax leak, and is among those who have been sacked from the firm in today's announcement.

"Accountability is critical to improving our culture and based on our investigation to date, it is clear that the conduct of a number of partners fell short of what was expected of them," Ms Stubbins said.
"They are now being held accountable for their misconduct.
"While we cannot change the past, we can control our actions today and in the future.
"Moving forward, the PwC Australia management team will continue to take all appropriate steps to improve the firm’s culture and standards."
